repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: `vim.treesitter.foldexpr()` is very slow when the parser is not
available (when `get_parser()` fails) and the number of lines is big.

This results in Nvim freezing for seconds when opening a buffer with no
treesitter parser is available.


Analysis: The reason of the slowdown is as follows:

- When there is no parser available for the buffer, `get_parser()` will
  throw an error and thus no FoldInfo cache will be stored.
- The treesitter foldexpr function will be called for every single line
  in the buffer.
- Therefore, when there is no parser available, `get_parser()` will be
  called once for each of the lines --- too often times as many as the
  number of lines (when opening the buffer).

Solution:

- Result of `get_parser()` even if it throws should be cached, so that
  `get_parser()` won't be called again for the same buffer. Under this
  implementation, an empty FoldInfo will be stored for the buffer.

- The FoldInfo cache should be invalidated and cleared when the buffer
  gets detached (|nvim_buf_detach_event|), because parser could become
  available in the future.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -359,13 +358,26 @@ function M.foldexpr(lnum)
   lnum = lnum or vim.v.lnum
   local bufnr = api.nvim_get_current_buf()
 
-  local parser = vim.F.npcall(ts.get_parser, bufnr)
-  if not parser then
-    return '0'
-  end
-
   if not foldinfos[bufnr] then
     foldinfos[bufnr] = FoldInfo.new()
+
+    -- Make sure to invalidate the foldinfo cache upon |nvim_buf_detach_event|
+    vim.api.nvim_buf_attach(bufnr, false, {

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
      -- get_parser() is expensive, especially when the parser is not available.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -359,13 +358,26 @@ function M.foldexpr(lnum)
   lnum = lnum or vim.v.lnum
   local bufnr = api.nvim_get_current_buf()
 
-  local parser = vim.F.npcall(ts.get_parser, bufnr)
-  if not parser then
-    return '0'
-  end
-
   if not foldinfos[bufnr] then
     foldinfos[bufnr] = FoldInfo.new()
+
+    -- Make sure to invalidate the foldinfo cache upon |nvim_buf_detach_event|
+    vim.api.nvim_buf_attach(bufnr, false, {
+      on_detach = function()
+        foldinfos[bufnr] = nil
+      end,
+    })
+
+    ---@type LanguageTree?
+    local parser = vim.F.npcall(ts.get_parser, bufnr)
+    if not parser then
+      -- get_parser() is expensive, especially when the parser is not avilable.

comment_regular_data.body:
Problem: In my environments, Nvim freezes for around 13 seconds when opening a buffer with ~40000 lines (e.g. [`:GV`](https://github.com/junegunn/gv.vim) on the neovim repository, or any large log (plain text) file) where treesitter parser is not available.

Profiling:

```
< $VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua:102       error("no parser for '" .. lang .. "' language, see :help treesitter-parsers")
< $VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua:113   language.add(lang)
< $VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/treesitter.lua:41                 local self = LanguageTree.new(bufnr, lang, opts)
< $VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/treesitter.lua:108                parsers[bufnr] = M._create_parser(bufnr, lang, opts)
< pcall
< vim/F.lua:0
< $VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/treesitter/_fold.lua:360          local parser = vim.F.npcall(ts.get_parser, bufnr)

```

and `vim.treesitter.get_parser()` searches the runtime directory for non-existent `{lang}.so` for so many times... :)

This could happen easily, for instance, when the treesitter foldexpr is used as a global option (i.e. `set foldexpr=v:lua.vim.treesitter.foldexpr()`) rather than buffer-local option (i.e. `setlocal foldexpr=v:lua.vim.treesitter.foldexpr()`) only when treesitter parser is available.

Note: another possible solution, in retrospect, is to `vim.func._memoize` a local function `vim.F.npcall(get_parser, ...)` so that the invocation of `get_parser` can be cached across adjacent foldexpr calls. In this way we don't need to store such buffers into the FoldInfo cache. But in this way `get_parser` might still be called quite often while editing or on other `|nvim_buf_changedtick_event|`s, which has a negative impact on the performance.
Alternative: make `get_parser()` smarter (e.g., memoized)? I'd assume that the same issue affects other treesitter functionality, like `indent`.

> Alternative: make `get_parser()` smarter (e.g., memoized)? I'd assume that the same issue affects other treesitter functionality, like `indent`.

Hmm, that's a very good point -- probably that could be a more universal solution. Indeed the problem could extend beyond foldexpr; though Nvim core doesn't have the treesitter indentexpr yet (note: nvim-treesitter currently implements memoization on its own to avoid such a perf problem).

Currently `get_parser()` will memoize and avoid reading the filesystem *if parsers were available*, but no memoization when it's not. So we could make it memoize even when the parser is unavailable, maybe introducing an error-safe, memoization-friendly version of `vim.treesitter.get_parser()`, or wrap it by default like `vim.treesitter.query.get()` (if errors are also to be memoized).

Note for myself: We should also better document the behavior of `get_parser` accordingly (i.e. whether it memoizes, throws when parser is not available, etc.)

Just note to be careful not to over-memoize things as it can lead to unideal situations. 

One thing I do it a lot is to run `TSInstall lang`, `:e!` when I need to quickly installed a parser for a filetype I haven't used before. Such memoization could potentially break this.
That's a plugin problem, though; `TSInstall` could easily invalidate the cache. We've been pretty consistent in our messaging that "hot reloading" is not really something Neovim supports, though.

> Just note to be careful not to over-memoize things as it can lead to unideal situations.

Exactly! the lifecycle of cache/memoization matters. I believe it should be fine as long as we have the buf detach handler.

The way I chose in this PR takes such situations (reload the buffer via `:e!`) into consideration, as per |nvim_buf_detach_event|. I will add tests about such case. `FileType` events should also be added. I will check BufReadPost as well, but I think this is already handled by the |nvim_buf_detach_event|.

With `vim.func._memoize` (on lua GC) the cache will invalidate quite more often. Or `memoize_by_buf_tick` as done in the old nvim-treesitter fold expr (https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/blob/master/lua/nvim-treesitter/fold.lua#L10) but I guess we deviated from that way on purpose...?

> With vim.func._memoize (on lua GC) the cache will invalidate quite more often. 

If we _can_ use that, that would be ideal. Maybe "more often" is still rare enough. Would it be possible to make some benchmarks so we can compare the approaches objectively?

> That's a plugin problem, though; `TSInstall` could easily invalidate the cache. We've been pretty consistent in our messaging that "hot reloading" is not really something Neovim supports, though.

Yes it is a plugin problem. Before it didn't need to worry about cache coherency, and now it will. That needs to be taken into consideration.

This isn't the same as hot-reloading. As soon as the parser becomes available, it will be useable. `vim.loader` is designed in such a way to behave just as gracefully. This is exactly why we currently only memoize _if_ we find a parser.

With that said, the GC runs often enough that this isn't likely to be a problem. I just wanted to note about eagerly memoizing stuff.

> With vim.func._memoize (on lua GC) the cache will invalidate quite more often. Or memoize_by_buf_tick as done in the old nvim-treesitter fold expr ([nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter@master/lua/nvim-treesitter/fold.lua#L10](https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/blob/master/lua/nvim-treesitter/fold.lua?rgh-link-date=2024-02-11T10%3A12%3A26Z#L10)) but I guess we deviated from that way on purpose...?

Only for simplicity. `foldexpr` is tied to a buffer so memoizing on buftick could make sense.

@clason should we move any further conversations here? RE: https://github.com/LazyVim/LazyVim/issues/1581#issuecomment-2310611839 and https://github.com/echasnovski/mini.nvim/issues/1151#issuecomment-2308453218
No, let's keep this PR focused on the technical details, the context is not needed.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: perf(treesitter): fix slow foldexpr when parser is not available
